title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON — On a night when the Boston Celtics threw everything they had at the Chicago Bulls, one man answered every challenge with an icy, historic resolve. Michael Jordan, defying the passage of time and the pressure of a hostile Garden, authored a playoff masterpiece for the ages, scoring a game-high **46 points** to will the Bulls to a pivotal 117-106 victory in 1997.

From the opening tip, it was clear Jordan was operating on a different plane. He sliced through the Celtics' defense with a relentless fury, a one-man offensive orchestra tuning up for a symphony of scoring. While teammate Scottie Pippen provided a crucial all-around foundation with 16 points and 7 assists, the night belonged to His Airness. Every Celtic run was met with a Jordan response—a fallaway jumper, a driving layup through traffic, a dagger three-pointer.

The Celtics, led by Antoine Walker's 22 points and Rick Fox's 20, fought valiantly. But they were ultimately powerless against a singular force of nature. Jordan’s 46 points were not just a number; they were a statement, a relentless execution that broke the spirit of a proud franchise and its fans.

In the final moments, as the game slipped away, the Boston Garden crowd, often a cauldron of animosity for visiting legends, could only watch in a state of resigned awe. They weren't just witnessing a defeat; they were bearing witness to history, to the indomitable will of the game's greatest player, once again elevating his team on his shoulders and marching them one step closer to another championship.
